table_alias: Visa eligibility details from Global Mobility App
table_description: The table EmployeeVisaEligbilityNavi is used to store information about the visa eligibility of employees based on their country. It includes details about the rules and visa descriptions. ALWAYS include VisaDescription and EligibilityDescription columns in the your DAX query, alongside the columns requested in the user question.

schema.description: This column stores the name of the country of the employee. Use country names such as Russia, Czech Republic, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Ireland etc. For USA and United Kingdom use 'USA' and 'United Kingdom' respectively in FILTER conditions as specified in the original guidance.
This column stores the description of the rules for visa eligibility for the employee based on their country.
Always use CONTAINSSTRING in DAX when filtering this column values to ensure partial matches are captured: CONTAINSSTRING([ColumnName], "SearchValue")

This column stores the description of the visa that the employee is eligible for based on their country and the rules. Never use abbreviations in FILTER conditions; use full forms (for example 'Work Permit').
This column stores Job Level criteria for visa eligibility of employees.

table_alias: Visa process document details from Global Mobility App
table_description: This table VisaProcessDocumentsNavi contains information about the visa process documents for employees in different countries. ALWAYS include VisaDescription column in your DAX query, alongside the columns requested in the user question.

schema.description: This column stores the email ID of the employee.
This column stores the unique identification number of the employee.
This column stores the name of the country where the visa process is being carried out. Use 'USA' or 'United Kingdom' where appropriate as noted in the original guidance.
This column stores the name of the document required for the visa process.
This column stores the name of the visa process (e.g., Extension Petition, New Petition, Visa Stamping).
This column stores a description of the visa. Always refer to this column whenever ICT related questions with respect to visa documents are asked. Never use abbreviations in FILTER conditions.

table_description: The Project Details table provides comprehensive metadata about projects within the organization, supporting project management, financial tracking, and organizational reporting. It includes identifiers, organizational units, contract types, and fiscal period information to facilitate accurate categorization and analysis. The Master Customer Code column contains unique alphanumeric codes assigned to master customers, linking project data to aggregated customer records. The Service Line Unit column identifies the primary division or department responsible for the project, such as IT Services, Human Resources, or Marketing. The Service Line Unit 2 column offers additional granularity by specifying a secondary unit or sub-division associated with the project. The Project PU column captures the name or identifier of the primary unit managing the project, aiding in resource allocation and performance tracking. The Master Project Code column holds unique alphanumeric identifiers for each project, ensuring consistent referencing across systems. The Revenue Credit Unit column represents the unit or currency used to record revenue credits for the project, such as USD or EUR. The Contract Type column specifies the legal and financial framework of the project, including types like Fixed-price, Time and Materials, or Cost Plus. The Period[Month] column contains abbreviated month names (e.g., Jan, Feb, Mar) representing the calendar month of the data entry. The Period[txtFiscalYear] column indicates the fiscal year using the format FYXX, such as FY23, FY24, or FY25. The Period[Fiscal Quarter] column denotes the specific fiscal quarter in the format FYXX - QY, such as FY24 - Q1 or FY24 - Q3. This table enables detailed project-level analysis across time periods, organizational units, and financial structures.

schema.description: This column in the Project Details table contains the unique alphanumeric codes assigned to master customers. Each code serves as an identifier that links to a master customer record, which aggregates data from various sources or sub-accounts related to that customer. The data type of this column is a string, indicating that the codes are composed of a combination of letters and numbers.

The Service Line Unit column in the Project Details table represents the specific division or unit within the organization that is responsible for the project. This column contains string values that identify the department or team, such as IT Services, Human Resources, or Marketing. This information is crucial for understanding which part of the organization the project pertains to, facilitating resource allocation, and tracking project performance by department.

This column in the Project Details table contains textual data representing the secondary unit or division within the service line that is associated with a specific project. It provides additional granularity on the organizational structure or specific focus area within the service line that is relevant to the project. The data is stored as strings, which may include names or codes representing different units or divisions.

The Project PU column in the Project Details table contains the name or identifier of the projects primary unit or department responsible for the project. This column is of string data type, which means it holds text data that can include letters, numbers, and special characters. The data in this column is crucial for categorizing projects by their managing units, facilitating project tracking, and resource allocation within the organization.

The Master Project Code column in the Project Details table contains unique alphanumeric identifiers assigned to each project. These codes are used to uniquely identify and reference projects within the organizations project management system. The data type of this column is String, which allows it to store a combination of letters and numbers. This column is crucial for linking project-related data across various tables and reports, ensuring consistent project tracking and management.

The Revenue Credit Unit column in the Project Details table represents the unit of measurement or the currency in which the revenue credits are calculated and recorded for a specific project. This could include units such as USD, EUR, or any other applicable currency or point system used to quantify the financial credits attributed to the projects revenue generation. The data type of this column is String, indicating that the values are stored as text.

The Contract Type column in the Project Details table contains textual data representing the type of contract associated with each project. This column specifies the legal agreement or arrangement category under which the project operates, such as Fixed-price, Time and Materials, Cost Plus, etc. It helps in understanding the financial and operational framework agreed upon for the project.

This column represents the months of a calendar year.The values in this column contains the abbreviations of the months like Jan, Feb, Mar, Apr, May, Jun, Jul, Aug, Sep, Oct, Nov, Dec. Each value corresponds to a specific month in the calendar.
The FiscalYear column indicates the fiscal year associated with the data entry. It uses an abbreviation format consisting of FY followed by the corresponding year, such as FY23, FY24, FY25.

The Fiscal Quarter column denotes the specific quarter within a fiscal year to which the data entry belongs. It follows a standardized format, such as FYXX - QY, where XX represents the fiscal year and Y represents the quarter. For instance, FY24 - Q1 refers to the first quarter of fiscal year 2024, FY24 - Q3 represents the third quarter of fiscal year 2024, and so on.

table_description: The Revenue table is part of the Finpulse V5 cube and supports the dataassist use case, providing key financial metrics for evaluating the companys income generation. It includes measures that help assess overall revenue performance across different timeframes and currency contexts. The Revenue Total measure represents the aggregate income generated from the sale of goods or services related to the companys core operations. This includes all revenue streams such as product sales, service fees, and other business activities, before any deductions like discounts, returns, or allowances. It serves as a critical metric for evaluating the effectiveness of sales and marketing strategies over a specific accounting period. The Revenue (Mar 31 Current Fx) Total measure captures the total revenue recorded on March 31st, calculated using the foreign exchange rates prevailing on that date. It includes all revenue streams converted into the reporting currency, providing a snapshot of financial performance while accounting for currency fluctuations. Together, these measures enable comprehensive analysis of revenue trends and support strategic financial planning.

schema.description: The Revenue Total measure in the Revenue table represents the aggregate amount of income generated from the sale of goods or services related to the companys primary operations. This measure typically includes all revenue streams, such as product sales, service fees, and other business activities, before any deductions like discounts, returns, or allowances. It is a critical financial metric used to assess the total effectiveness of a companys sales and marketing strategies over a specific accounting period.

This measure represents the total revenue recorded on March 31st, calculated using the current foreign exchange rates at that date. It includes all revenue streams and transactions converted to the reporting currency based on the exchange rates prevailing on March 31st. This metric is crucial for understanding the companys financial performance on that specific date, taking into account the impact of currency fluctuations on international transactions.

table_description: The Expense table provides key financial metrics related to the companys cost structure, supporting profitability analysis, cost management, and financial planning. It includes measures that help evaluate both direct and overall expenses incurred during business operations. The Operating Margin % (also referred to as OM%) is a profitability ratio that measures the percentage of profit a company generates from its operations before taxes and interest. It is calculated by dividing operating income by net sales and is expressed as a percentage. This metric helps assess how efficiently a company manages its operating expenses relative to its revenue, with a higher percentage indicating better cost control and profitability. The Expense Total (also known as Total Cost) represents the aggregate amount of all expenses recorded, including operational costs, salaries, utilities, and other expenditures. It provides a comprehensive view of the companys total financial outflow for a given period. The Cost of Revenue - Direct (or Total Direct Cost) captures the direct costs associated with producing goods or services sold by the company, such as direct materials and labor. It excludes indirect costs like administrative or sales expenses and is essential for analyzing gross profit margins and understanding the cost efficiency of revenue-generating activities.

schema.description: Operating Margin % or OM% also known as operating profit margin or return on sales, is a profitability ratio that measures the percentage of profit a company produces from its operations, prior to subtracting taxes and interest charges. Operating Margin % measure can also be referred as OM% . It is calculated by dividing the operating income (or operating profit) by net sales (revenue). The result is expressed as a percentage. This measure helps in assessing the efficiency of a company in managing its operating expenses relative to its revenue. A higher percentage indicates a more profitable company that has better control over its costs compared to its competitors.

The Expense Total or total cost measure in the Expense table represents the aggregate amount of all expenses recorded. Expense total can also be referred as total cost. This includes all types of expenses such as operational costs, salaries, utilities, and any other expenditures. The total is calculated by summing up all individual expense entries in the table, providing a comprehensive view of the total financial outflow for a given period.

The Cost of Revenue - Direct or total direct cost measure in the Expense table represents the total direct costs associated with the production of goods or services sold by the company. This typically includes direct materials, direct labor, and any other direct costs incurred during the manufacturing or production process. It excludes indirect expenses such as administrative and sales expenses. This measure is crucial for analyzing the direct expenses tied to revenue generation and helps in assessing the gross profit margin.

table_description: The Effort table captures cumulative data related to production activities across various projects, products, or time periods within the organization. It supports operational efficiency analysis, resource planning, and productivity tracking. The key measure in this table is Production Months Total, which represents the total number of months during which production activities were actively carried out. This measure aggregates production durations to provide a comprehensive overview of the total effort expended in production. It is typically used to assess productivity levels, evaluate operational throughput, and plan resource allocation over a specified fiscal period or across different production cycles.

schema.description: The Production Months Total measure in the Effort table represents the cumulative total of all months during which production activities were actively carried out. This measure aggregates the duration of production across different projects, products, or time periods within the organization, providing a comprehensive overview of the total production effort expended. It is typically used to assess productivity, plan resource allocation, and evaluate operational efficiency over a specified fiscal period or across different production cycles.

table_description: The Cockpit Linked Code Details table is a foundational component of the Cockpit Dashboard, designed to provide a unified and detailed view of project metadata across enterprise systems such as PROPEL and OMS. It enables comprehensive tracking and management of project codes, customer associations, organizational units, and delivery structures. The table supports governance and operational oversight by capturing key identifiers like project codes (ProjectCode), customer accounts (CustomerCode), and their hierarchical relationships through fields such as LinkedTo, MasterProjectCode, and IsLinked. It also includes organizational classifications like Unit, PracticeUnit, DeliveryUnit, and SubUnit, which help in segmenting and analyzing data across business units. Managerial accountability is embedded through login identifiers of various stakeholders including Project Managers, Delivery Managers, Senior Delivery Managers, Group Project Managers, and Senior Project Managers. Quality governance is facilitated by capturing the login details of Account Quality Managers, Practice Quality Managers, and Quality Anchors. The table tracks project lifecycle attributes such as EndDate, PROPELEndDate, and ProjectAgeing, which are essential for understanding project timelines and aging. Operational metrics like PROPELFTE and PROPELTeamSize provide insights into resource allocation and team composition. Risk management is supported through the RiskStatus column, which categorizes projects based on their exposure levels. The table also includes fields like ManagedBy, Status, and ProjectStatus to distinguish between Infosys-managed and customer-managed projects, and to reflect their current operational state. Technology and tooling information is captured through columns like tools, technology, Service, and ServiceOfferings, which help in identifying the technical stack and service applicability for each project. Derived measures such as Percentage of Customer managed projects and Total MI codes offer strategic insights into project ownership and distribution. This table is refreshed periodically and serves as a critical data source for dashboards and analytics used by Delivery Managers, Practice Heads, and Quality Anchors.

schema.description: The unique identifier for a project /projectcode/code within the organization. Used to link various project-specific data points and is essential for tracking and managing project-related information across systems. Some times , these project codes are also referred to as Linked Codes /Managed Linked Code/Managed Independent/IM code in PROPEL/IOP application or system

The column customercodeor referred as account, account associated with each of the customers account. This is used to identify and link data specifically to a customer account, allowing for customer-specific or account-specific reporting and analysis within the system,This can also be mentioned as account from the end users

The column unit is used to categorize and analyze data based on organizational units, aiding in unit-specific reporting and management which is associated with any project /projectcode/ code or to any user. This can be also referred as unit
The column PracticeUnit refers to the practice unit to which the project code or code belongs to. This can be also referred as practise unit or practice unit or in short like PU.
The column DeliveryUnit refers to the delivery unit or DU to which the project code or code belongs to. This can be also referred as delivery unit or in short like DU.
The current status of the project /projectcode/ code. This field may represent whether the project code is Open or Active, Closed.

This field provides a specific status for a project or code in the PROPEL/IOP system/application that is more detailed than the general Status column. It is valuable for gaining insight into the precise phase or condition of a project in the system/application. Examples of possible status values include: Managed - Independently: Indicates that the project or code is being independently managed within the PROPEL/IOP system/application. Managed - Linked: Indicates that the project or code is linked to another project or code and is being managed accordingly in the PROPEL/IOP system/application. Not Managed: Indicates that the project or code is not currently being actively managed in the PROPEL/IOP system/application.

References the unique identifier for a project /projectcode/code is linked to. This allows for relational tracking within the PROPEL system. Usually Linked To Code acts as an Execution/Main Code /Parent Code.

This field represents the allocation of resources in a project, measured in full-time equivalents (FTE). The value in this field typically consists of a decimal number indicating the proportion of resources dedicated to a specific project or task. This information is helpful for workforce and resource allocation analysis. The calculation of this field depends on the type of project code: If the project code is independently managed code OMS Master, the calculation is based on the active Alcon resources from the OMS Master code and all linked codes in PROPEL.If the project code is independently managed code OMS Child, the calculation is based on the active Alcon resources from the OMS Child code and all linked codes associated with this code.

The unique login identifier / Mail ID/ User ID/ email address of the Project Manager (PM) assigned to a specific project. The user facilitates communication, task allocation, and tracks project management. If the question asked is related to self like (where I am PM) use : SUBSTITUTE(LOWER(USERNAME()), "itlinfosys\ ", "").

The unique login identifier / Mail ID/ User ID/ email address of the Delivery Manager (DM) overseeing the project. The DM is assigned to a specific project.If the question asked is related to self like (where I am PM) use : SUBSTITUTE(LOWER(USERNAME()), "itlinfosys\ ", "").

The unique login identifier / Mail ID/ User ID/ email address of the Senior Delivery Manager (SDM) associated to a specific project. If the question asked is related to self like (where I am PM) use : SUBSTITUTE(LOWER(USERNAME()), "itlinfosys\ ", "").

The unique login identifier / Mail ID/ User ID/ email address of the Group Project Manager (GPM) responsible for a cluster or group of related projects. If the question asked is related to self like (where I am PM) use : SUBSTITUTE(LOWER(USERNAME()), "itlinfosys\ ", "").

The unique login identifier / Mail ID/ User ID/ email address of the Account Quality Manager (AQM) for a specific project. The AQM is assigned at the Account level in PROPEL and remains the same for all projects within that Account. Use CONTAINSSTRING as operator while using this column in the query. If the user question requires this column to be empty or blank, always include the following condition in the query: QualityAnchorLoginId = ""

The unique login identifier / Mail ID/ User ID/ email address of the Practice Quality Manager (PQM) dedicated to maintaining quality standards within the project. The PQM is assigned at the Practice Unit level in PROPEL and remains the same for all projects within that Practice Unit. Use CONTAINSSTRING as operator while using this column in the query. If the user question requires this column to be empty or blank, always include the following condition in the query: QualityAnchorLoginId = ""

The unique login identifier / Mail ID/ User ID/ email address of the Quality Anchor (QA or SQA), the primary quality assurance lead responsible for the project. This data is setup in PROPEL. There can be multiple Quality Anchors for a single project. If the user question requires this column to be empty or blank, always include the following condition in the query: QualityAnchorLoginId = "". Use CONTAINSSTRING as operator while using this column in the query.

The SPMLoginId column contains the unique login identifier of the Senior Project Manager(SPM) assigned to the project. If the question asked is related to self like (where I am PM) use : SUBSTITUTE(LOWER(USERNAME()), "itlinfosys\ ", "").
The ManagedBy column contains the information whether a project or project code or code is managed by Infosys or Customer.
The RiskStatus column represents the riskstatus or alert data or risk level for a project code or code or project. It has values such as Critical ,High2 ,High , Not High Risk and Proactive high risk.
The EndDate column  represents the actual end date of a project code or code.It typically refers to the date when the project was officially completed or closed.

The PROPELEndDate column refers the maximum or max end date of all the linked or child codes of the main code or project code. If the main code or project code doesnt have any child or linked codes, then the PROPELEndDate will be same as of EndDate column.
The IsLinked column refers whether the project code or code or project is linked or not. It has value as Yes or No.

The Service column contains a single value or list of selected or applicable service information or data for a project or project code or code in propel.It is also referred as PM Plan Service. For example : testing, cloud,development,testing,cloud,development,.... Use CONTAINSSTRING as operator while using this column in the query.
The column MasterProjectCode refers to the master project code setup in OMS.
The column MasterCustomerCode refers to the Master Customer code setup in OMS.
The column “SubUnit” refers to the subunit or SU to which or sub unit the project code or code belongs to.
The PROPELTeamSize column refers the actual headcount or team size or alloctaions or resource count of a project code or code.

ProjectAgeing or Project age or Age of the project code or project or code refers to the duration or length of the time that a project or code has been ongoing. It is calculated by subtracting the projects start date from the current date.
This measure refers to the percentage of customer managed projects and managed independently codes out of the total projects managed independently.
This measure is used to give the total  count of Managed Independently projects.

The column Tools refers to the tools that are used in the Project/Project code.  It contains a single value or list of selected or applicable tools information or data for a project or project code or code in propel. These tools can refer to a range of software, hardware, or programming languages that are employed in the development or execution of the project. It is also referred as "PM Plan Tools".

The column Technology represents the specific technologies used in the implementation or execution of the project or project code or code. It provides information about the technology stack or infrastructure employed to develop, deploy, or operate the project. It may contain a single value or a list of relevant technologies utilized in the project, depending on the complexity and requirements. It is also referred as "PM Plan Technology". It may include items such as Front-end technologies like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React js, Angular js, Back-end technologies like Nodejs, Ruby on Rails, Database technologies like MySQL, MongoDB, PostgreSQL, Server technologies like Apache, Cloud platforms: Amazon WebServices (AWS), Google apps, Microsoft Azure.

The ServiceOfferings column contains a single value or list of selected or applicable service information or data for a project or project code or code in propel. For example : testing, cloud Use CONTAINSSTRING as operator while using this column in the query.

table_description: The ELF Next due by Calculation table is used to manage and monitor the scheduling and status of Employee Level Feedback (ELF) submissions across various projects. It captures the type of feedback form used through the FormType column, which distinguishes between different formats such as ELF Long Format Agile, ELF Agile, ELF Non Agile, and ELF Short Format, each with its respective rating scale. The RatingOrScore column records the overall score or rating given for the feedback, which is treated as a string value and represents the evaluation of the feedback scope. The CustomerFeedback column identifies the feedback mechanism employed in the project, including options like Client/Vendor Tool, External Surveys, Happiness Index, Infosys ELF, NPS, and other informal methods such as interviews or emails. The Frequency column defines how often feedback is expected, with values such as Monthly, Quarterly, Bi-Annually, or Ad-hoc, which directly influence the scheduling of feedback cycles. The MaxRatingScale column indicates the maximum rating scale applicable to the form type, typically either a 5-point or 7-point scale. The ELFReceivedDate column logs the date on which feedback was received, helping track submission timelines. The Next due by column calculates the upcoming due date for feedback based on the defined frequency, ensuring timely follow-ups. The ELF Received Status column shows whether feedback has been received for the current cycle, aiding in tracking completion. Lastly, the ELFExemptedFlag column identifies whether a project or code is exempted from the ELF process, allowing for exceptions to be managed appropriately.

schema.description: The FormType column  captures the specific type of ELF (Employee Feedback) template used for collecting feedback from employees. It helps in distinguishing between different types or categories of feedback forms. The different types of form types are ELF long format agile or  ELFLONGFORMATAGILE - 5 Scale ,ELF agile or ELFAGILE - 7 Scale, ELF long format or ELFLONGFORMAT - 5 Scale,  ELF Non agile or ELFNONAGILE - 7 Scale , ELF Short format or ELFSHORTFORMAT - 5 Scale and ELF Short format agile or ELFSHORTFORMATAGILE - 5 Scale.

The RatingOrScore column holds the overall score given for the ELF form type. It is also called as Score or ELF Score or Overall score or Rating. This score represents the assessment or evaluation of the scope defined for the feedback. Consider values as String For example: 1,2,3, etc. .

The CustomerFeedback column indicates the ELF or Engagement Level Feedback or alternate feedback or Client Feedback mechanism used in the project. It has feedbacks of Client/Vendor Tool/Portal,External Surveys,Happiness Index,Infosys ELF,NPS,Others (Interviews, Emails etc),Rater Card.

The Frequency column  indicates the duration for which the ELF feedback is expected and collected. This could be a Monthly, Quarterly, Bi-Annually, or Ad-hoc, determining how often the feedback is gathered.
The MaxRatingScale column indicates the maximum or max rating scale for the ELF form type. The value is a string. It can be either "5" point scale or "7" point scale.
The ELFReceivedDate column  records the date when the feedback for the ELF form type was received. This helps to track when the feedback was submitted and provides a timeline for analysis.

schema.column_name: ELF Next due by Calculation[Next due by]
schema.description: The Next due by column or Next Due date represents the upcoming due date for the feedback. It signifies the date by which the next round of feedback should be received. This is calculated based on the frequency defined for the project.

schema.column_name: ELF Next due by Calculation[ELF Received Status]
schema.description: The ELF Next due by Calculation[ELF Received Status] column  indicates whether the feedback has been received or not for the applicable frequency. It helps to track the completion status of feedback collection for a given frequency.
The ELFExemptedFlag column indicates whether the project or project code or code is exempted from ELF or feedback.

table_description: The BEST Details table is used to track and manage the BEST Assessment ratings for project codes across the organization. It captures the current rating of a project through the Rating column, which includes values such as Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum, Diamond, Plastic, and Not Rated. These ratings reflect the maturity and compliance level of a project based on internal assessment criteria. The NextAssessmentDueDate column indicates the scheduled date for the next BEST assessment, while the LastBESTAssessedDate column records the most recent date on which the project was assessed. The OpenFindings column provides the count of unresolved findings or action items identified during the assessment, highlighting areas that require attention. The AssessmentOverDue column measures the time elapsed since the last assessment, helping to identify overdue evaluations. The Due for BEST Rating column flags whether a project is due for reassessment, based on the condition that the next assessment due date is more than 45 days from the last assessment date. In addition to these columns, the table includes several measures that support performance tracking and strategic analysis. The Gold plus percentage measure calculates the proportion of Infosys-managed projects with a PROPELFTE greater than 4 that have received a Gold, Platinum, or Diamond rating. The Projects in GOLD measure provides the total count of projects rated as Gold, while the Projects in Not Rated measure counts those without a formal rating. The Projects in Gold+ measure aggregates the count of projects rated as Gold, Platinum, or Diamond, offering a consolidated view of high-performing projects.

schema.description: The Rating column contains the BEST Assessment rating for a code or project code. Rating has values as "Bronze","Diamond","Gold","Plastic","Platinum","Silver","Not Rated". If Ratings are asked for "Gold+" consider it as Gold, Platinum and Diamond rating.
The NextAssessmentDueDate column contains the due date for next project BEST Assessment or project BEST rating.
The LastBESTAssessedDate column contains Last or previous or latest BEST Assessment Rating date for a given project.
The OpenFindings column contains the number or count of Open findings or findings or BEST Action items or process gaps based on assessment for a given project code or code.
The AssessmentOverDue column or Assessment Age contains BEST Assessment ageing or date lapsed since last assessment for a given project code or code.

The column Due for BEST Rating represents whether the BEST rated project or code is due for BEST rating. If the value in this column is Y, it means that the project is due for a BEST rating assessment. In order for a project to be due for a BEST rating, the next assessment due date should be more than 45 days from the last assessed date or the last assessment date.

This measure calculates the Percentage of Gold+ projects to the percent of Infosys managed projects with PROPELFTE or FTE greater than 4 for projects having rating as Gold, Platinum and Diamond out of the Total Infosys managed projects with PROPELFTE or FTE greater than 4.
This measure will give the total count of Project codes with BEST rating as Gold.
This measure will give the total count of Project codes with BEST rating as Not Rated.
This measure will give the total count of Project codes with BEST rating as Gold or Platinum or Diamond.
